content.description: Multiple steep and tricky sections with good rests lead to an easy finish.
content.location: #15. The first route you encounter as you approach(as of spring 21)

content.description: Big moves on good holds get you through the initial overhang and to easier ground. Jugs lead you up the overhang past a distinct crux on smaller holds and to the top.
content.location:
Not yet tagged

Starts a few feet right of Physical Basalt #16

content.description: Low angle climbing with a few 5.6 moves sprinkled in.
content.location: #10 The only larger rock on the downhill side of the trail is three feet tall and pointy.  There are two routes directly across from it.  This is the left one.

content.description: A steep section climbs past three or four bolts and lower angle terrain brings you to anchors
content.location:
#6 tag

to the immediate right Of #5

content.description: Wander past a few bolts and through a distinct crux.  Tricky and a bit thought provoking.  One of the best routes at the upper cliff.
Easier climbing leads to a small bulge.  A tricky boulder problem with a very key hidden jug will lead you through the bulge to a pumpy finish.
content.location:
#7 tag

between #6 and #16

A few yards left of Choss and the Art of Bolt Placement is a small grassy ramp.  The route starts just down and left of this ramp.

content.description: This route follows the line of bolts up the overhanging wall past multiple boulders sections with good holds in between.  Sustained and puppy.
content.location:
Tag #16

This is the fourth route to the left of the pointed boulder. Starts just right of a small overhang.

content.description:
The route starts at a large rock platform right next to the trail.  Climb the shallow corner past to bolts to a ledge.  From here the rout steepens and contains a few bouldery cruxes. The last few bolts can be pumpy as the route is difficult to read and climbing is slow going.  Bolted on Mr. T's birthday!

I pity the fool that can't make it to the chains!
content.location:
tag #18

One of the first routes you encounter as you approach.  The base has a rock platform built next to the trail.

content.description: A steep tricky start leads to easier climbing above.
A steep tricky start leads to easier climbing above.
Fun low angle climbing with a few steeper 5.7 sections.
content.location: #11 The only larger rock on the downhill side of the trail is three feet tall and pointy.  There are two routes directly across from it.  This is the right one.

content.description: A slightly less than vertical route.
content.location:
Tag #19

located toward the left end of the wall between routes 6 and 7.

content.description: This route ascends the slight overhang a few feet left of Choss and the Art of Bolt Placement.    A line of bolts in a shallow groove leads you through a few thought provoking sections and easier ground.
content.protection: 8 bolts to anchors with rappel rings
content.location: #8 The route immediately left of Choss and the Art of Bold Placement.

content.description: The easiest route on the upper band.  A nice position with lots of bolts and fun climbing make for a great early lead.
content.location: #5. Ascends a low angled shallow scoop toward the left hand side of the wall.

climbs.name: Choss and the Art of Bolt Placement

content.description:
Begin on a detached pillar, climbing past a couple bolts. At the top of the pillar, step across to the main wall and continue climbing on blocky terrain to an anchor the top of the formation. The rock quality probably won't inspire confidence, but the length of the climb might be refreshing if you've only climbed at the lower cliff.

The name is a reference to the classic novel "Zen and The Art of Motorcycle Maintenance".... and the rock quality of the upper cliff. This was the first route I bolted at Wallula
content.location: Make your way into the drainage south of the formation.  Follow this trail up the drainage before cutting across the slope to the wall. This route starts on a notable, detached pilar

content.description: A fun and easy climb with a great view.
content.location: #1. The left-most route at the upper band (as of spring 2021).

content.description: Follow a line of bolts weaving your way around or over a few bulges.  Fun climbing!
content.location:
Tag #13

a few hundred feet climbers right of the pointy Boulder.

content.description: A steeper short section leads past two bolts to easier ground.
Climb a shallow low angle dish past a few bolts.  The route steepens as the groove becomes a corner.  Push and stem your way up the well featured corner to the top.
